description: From Middle English abyen, abien, abiggen, from Old English ābyċġan (“to buy; pay for; buy off; requite; recompense; redeem; perform; execute”), from Proto-Germanic *uzbugjaną, equivalent to a- +‎ buy. Cognate with Gothic 𐌿𐍃𐌱𐌿𐌲𐌾𐌰𐌽 (usbugjan). Not related to abide.

verbs.description: aby (simple past and past participle abought, no other forms attested in Modern English)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To pay the penalty for (something); to atone for, to make amends. [from 12th c.]
(archaic, figuratively) To pay (something) as a penalty; to suffer (something). [from 12th c.]
(obsolete except Scotland) To endure or tolerate (something); to experience. [from 16th c.]
examples: Synonyms: brook, go on, hold on, put up with; see also Thesaurus:persist, Thesaurus:tolerate

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To pay for (something); to buy. [12th–16th c.]
examples: Synonyms: procure, purchase; see also Thesaurus:buy

entries.meaning: To pay the penalty; to atone. [12th–16th c.]
